review.title: Identifying Pairs in Simulated Bio-Medical Time-Series
review.abstract: The paper presents a time-series-based classification approach to identify similarities in pairs of simulated human-generated patterns. An example for a pattern is a time-series representing a heart rate during a specific time-range, wherein the time-series is a sequence of data points that represent the changes in the heart rate values. A bio-medical simulator system was developed to acquire a collection of 7,871 price patterns of financial instruments. The financial instruments traded in real-time on three American stock exchanges, NASDAQ, NYSE, and AMEX, simulate bio-medical measurements. The system simulates a human in which each price pattern represents one bio-medical sensor. Data provided during trading hours from the stock exchanges allowed real-time classification. Classification is based on new machine learning techniques: self-labeling, which allows the application of supervised learning methods on unlabeled time-series and similarity ranking, which applied on a decision tree learning algorithm to classify time-series regardless of type and quantity.
histories: arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1303.0073
review.COMMENTS: arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1303.0073

sections.text: An example of a pattern is a timeline that represents a heart rate over a given period of time, with the timeline showing a sequence of data points representing changes in heart rate values. A biological simulation system is designed to obtain a collection of 7,871 price patterns of Financial Instruments. Financial Instruments that are traded in real time are able to register and register in real time, and the system simulates a human in which each price pattern represents a biological-medical sensor.

sections.heading: II. A BIO-MEDICAL SIMULATOR FOR IDENTIFYING PAIRS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Overview
sections.text: In order to simulate the measurements of a large collection of biomedical sensors, a classification system and several calculation methods were developed. It consisted of three operational stages - 1) sampling - the method for capturing time series over a pre-defined period, 2) classification - the method for identifying similarities between time series and 3) tracking - the method of a user or an automatic monitoring process - the ability to observe in real time time time time time time time series that were classified as similar during the sample and classification phases and to act on them.

sections.heading: B. Sampling
sections.text: The sampling stage consisted of the sampling of m time series, which were sampled several times from time 1T to time 2T (Fig. 1). The sampling of time series includes an initial sampling of the values of m time series, which were measured at time 1T, several further sampling of the values of m time series (e.g. every ten seconds) and a final sampling of the values of m time series, which were measured at time 2T. The number of samples, n, is determined in advance, as is the interval between samples. However, there is no restriction to having an identical interval value between samples. When the sampling ends, the vectors of the values (e.g. prices, which represent financial instruments) are displayed as in (1).

sections.heading: C. Classification
sections.text: The classification phase identifies pairs of similarly behaving financial instruments. Steps are based on the application of several methods, including self-identification, decision-tree learning and similarity ranking. When the classification phase ends, a subset of the original time series is stored in a database, containing pairs of time series that behave similarly, described in more detail in Section III.

sections.heading: D. Tracking
sections.text: In addition to each financial instrument presented in real time, there are several parameters, including its current price (expressed in US dollars), the change in price since tracking began (expressed in percent) and its sector (Figure 2). A sector could have one of the following values: 1) Services, 2) Healthcare, 3) Utilities, 4) Financial services, 5) Consumer goods, 6) Basic materials, 7) Conglomerates, 8) Industrial goods and 9) Technology. The user has the option of presenting only pairs in which the financial instruments in each pair belong to the same sector. Financial instruments are visualized in real time so that the user can monitor and monitor the data collected.

sections.heading: B. Decision Tree Learning
sections.text: This year it has come to the point where it will be able to put itself at the top, "he said in an interview with the Deutsche Presse-Agentur." We have never waited so long to be able to find a solution, "he said." But we are not yet able to find a solution, "he told the Deutsche Presse-Agentur." We have never waited so long to be able to find a solution, "he told the Deutsche Presse-Agentur," but we are not yet able to find a solution. "

sections.heading: C. Similarity Ranking
sections.text: To obtain a similarity for a Financial Instrument consisting of a pair, a method of measuring the similarity is used (Fig. 4). Considering a Financial Instrument - the Financial Instrument referred to as S. queries the data structure of the decision tree. Similar behaving Financial Instruments are identified and sorted by the number of occurrences at the nodes also containing S. The Financial Instrument with the highest counter value is selected as part of the pair. If two or more Financial Instruments with an identical counter value are found, one of them is randomly selected. 4 Tn _ Tn-1 for a Financial Instrument represents the difference expressed as a percentage between the price recorded at the time Tn and the price recorded at the time Tn1.

sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: To evaluate the classification accuracy of the simulator, the sampling period followed by the classification (January 24, 2013, 15: 03: 50 PM - 15: 10: 06 PM) was observed. 202 pairs were identified as pairs, while in each pair the two Financial Instruments behaved similarly (see examples in Fig. 5). The 20 similarly behaved pairs with the same sector for the two Financial Instruments in a pair together with the Pearson Product-Moment Correlation Coefficient Values (r) for each pair are presented in Table A. The correlation of 90% of the pairs (18 of 20) was positive, indicating a high classification accuracy. The average of the 20 pairs was 0.63 (SD: 0.39).

sections.heading: V. DISCUSSION
sections.text: The provision of classifications for signals or time series is well discussed in the literature, but what is important here, as described in (1) - (4), is an improvement in self-labeling that facilitates the application of monitored learning methods to unlabeled datasets. Another important aspect facilitates the classification of time series - the similarity ranking applied to a decision tree learning algorithm to classify time series regardless of type and quantity.The methods described in the paper could be applied to a large collection of biomedical sensors - the simulator presented in the paper allows the acquisition and classification of unspecified time series measurements. Additional financial measurements, i.e. sensor measurements, could be acquired without changing the design and without having to develop additional software components. Another advantage of the methods is that they have the potential to reduce the complexity of sensors detected by ignition of sensors.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE RESEARCH
sections.text: The simulator is based on: a sampling method that enables the acquisition of samples of 7,871 financial instruments traded in real time on three American exchanges: NASDAQ, NYSE and AMEX; a classification method for identifying similarly behaved pairs; and a user interface that enables real-time observation of the identified pairs. Positive high correlations were repeatedly observed for pairs containing similarly identified patterns; the classification is based on new machine learning techniques: self-labeling that enables the application of monitored learning methods to blank time series and similarity ranking applied to a decision-tree learning algorithm for classifying time series regardless of type and quantity; and the classification approach proposes addressing the expected scalability constraints associated with multiple-sensing-based systems as it enables the classification of measurements regardless of the type and quantity of measurements.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: The author would like to pay tribute to Mr. David Orange, BSEE, JD and LLM (The University of Washington) for their tremendous support and help.

An example for a continuous assessment of EDA outside of a laboratory setting is provided in [20].

NeuroGlasses is a wearable physiological signal monitoring system [21]—the system acquires health-related signals by using OCZ NIA, a head-band with one neurosensory; a location-aware signal correction and a feature-based reconstruction approach were proposed to compensate signal distortion due to the variation of sensor location and other noises.

[22] describe an implementation of decision tree and artificial neural network algorithms to classify activities such as walking, running, and cycling; a data collection system was developed and provided measurements to 18 different signals, such as, altitude, audio, chest and wrist acceleration, EKG, humidity, light intensity, heart rate, respiratory effort, and skin temperature.

The method, Hidden Markov Event Model (HMEM), can be adapted to new movements and new sensors and was validated on a walking data-set by using sensors such as triaxial accelerometer and biaxial gyroscope [23].

Examples for futuristic sensors include physical-measuring wearable sensors that measure the level of dehydration [25], sensors that measure the level of exposure to sunlight, and sensors that measure weight and height.

metadata.abstractText: The paper presents a time-series-based classification approach to identify similarities in pairs of simulated humangenerated patterns. An example for a pattern is a time-series representing a heart rate during a specific time-range, wherein the time-series is a sequence of data points that represent the changes in the heart rate values. A bio-medical simulator system was developed to acquire a collection of 7,871 price patterns of financial instruments. The financial instruments traded in realtime on three American stock exchanges, NASDAQ, NYSE, and AMEX, simulate bio-medical measurements. The system simulates a human in which each price pattern represents one bio-medical sensor. Data provided during trading hours from the stock exchanges allowed real-time classification. Classification is based on new machine learning techniques: self-labeling, which allows the application of supervised learning methods on unlabeled time-series and similarity ranking, which applied on a decision tree learning algorithm to classify time-series regardless of type and quantity.
